items.title: Notebook example "Seasonality in time series data" has bugged Latex
items.body:
#### Describe the bug

The ["Unobserved components (frequency domain modeling)" section in "Seasonality in time series data"  notebook](https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/examples/notebooks/generated/statespace_seasonal.html#Unobserved-components-(frequency-domain-modeling)) has a markdown cell of latex that fails to render.

Checked on Firefox 79.0 (64-bit) and Chrome 84.0.4147.105 (Official Build) (64-bit)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30065865/90725820-f0e53800-e2ea-11ea-8669-44dd401ce5ae.png)

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

I believe the issue is caused by a double Latex closing `$$` in the markdown cell, [lines L147-L148 in the mentioned notebook](
https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blame/b6af4263d6ad6de4ebf45d9200fcc95d3afc44e1/examples/notebooks/statespace_seasonal.ipynb#L147-L148)

```latex
$$
$$
```
#### Expected Output

Latex code renders like [the notebook in the repository](https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/master/examples/notebooks/statespace_seasonal.ipynb)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30065865/90727086-eb88ed00-e2ec-11ea-8da6-3d553c3de70b.png)

#### Output of ``import statsmodels.api as sm; sm.show_versions()``

Not applicable.

items.title: mosaicplot turn off part of tick labels
items.body:
I wanted to turn off part of the tick labels (top x axis tick labels) because the third dimension has too long texts. I tried to use the axes.tick_params to override the mosaic function, but got no luck. I didn't want to set axes_label to False, as it will turn off all tick labels.

```
from statsmodels.graphics.mosaicplot import mosaic
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.colors as mcolors
import matplotlib.patches as mpatches
colormap = list(mcolors.TABLEAU_COLORS.values())

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 12))
ax.set_xlabel('Age')
ax.set_ylabel('Race')
# ax.set_xticklabels(df_mosaic.age_cat.unique())
# ax.set_yticklabels(df_mosaic.race_recode.unique())
legend_patch = [mpatches.Patch(color=colormap[i], label=label) for i, label in enumerate(df_mosaic.discharge.unique())]
ax.tick_params(axis='x', which='both', top=False, labeltop=False)
mosaic(df_mosaic, ['age_cat', 'race_recode', 'discharge'], ax=ax, labelizer=lambda x: '', gap=0.01, properties=color_mosaic)
plt.legend(handles=legend_patch, loc='center left', bbox_to_anchor=(1, 0.5), title='Discharge Type')
# plt.savefig('mosaic.jpg')
plt.show()
```

items.title: GLM is Broken in Python 3.8
items.body:
#### Describe the bug

Fitting a GLM works in Python 3.7 but does not work in Python 3.8.

#### Code Sample
The following works in Python 3.7 but does not work in Python 3.8:
```python
import numpy as np
import statsmodels.api as sm

np.random.seed(8)
n, d = 100, 10
x = np.random.rand(n,d)
y = np.random.randint(2, size=n)

sm_model = sm.GLM(y, x, family=sm.families.Binomial())
sm_model = sm_model.fit()
print(sm_model.llf)
```

In Python 3.8, the `fit` call produces lots of error messages that look like this:
```
python(97726,0x116394dc0) malloc: can't allocate region
:*** mach_vm_map(size=18446744071921549312, flags: 100) failed (error code=3)
python(97726,0x116394dc0) malloc: *** set a breakpoint in malloc_error_break to debug
init_dgelsd failed init
```

In Python 3.8 `sm_model.llf` is `nan`. In Python 3.7 it is a number. 

Removing the ` family=sm.families.Binomial()` from `sm.GLM(...)` (i.e. using Gaussian) still produces malloc errors, but does seem to produce the right model.

#### Expected Output

No malloc error in Python 3.8.

Also gives the correct answer, when using Binomial Family, in Python 3.8 

#### Output of ``import statsmodels.api as sm; sm.show_versions()``

items.title: DFM results change if columns are shuffled
items.body:
#### Describe the bug

Using the same dataset, but shuffling the order of the columns, sometimes results in different results for sm.DFM.  Specifically, the factor is at different scales.  

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

https://gist.github.com/DanielWeitzenfeld/1835112662bc489be6cc0a6bb170db25

The factors are the same shape, but at different scales.  In the notebook above, the difference is small, but in the example that motivated my posting this, the difference is an order of magnitude and seems to lead to significantly different fitted values after smoothing.  

I get that the model is poorly identified scale-wise.  It seems the only constraint on the scale of the factor is that the variance on the innovations is _I_.  But why does shuffling the columns lead to different scales?

items.title: AR model returns only NaNs as out-of-sample predictions
items.body:
#### Describe the bug

With a simple AR model, making predictions for points outside the sample values yields only NaNs.
Trying to predict only in-sample points works correctly.
Similar code with different data works correctly, suggesting that something is amiss in the training data; however, I do not understand what.

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible


```python
import pandas as pd
import statsmodels.tsa.api as tsa

hours = pd.period_range(start='2020/06/17 23', end='2020/07/01 23', freq='H').strftime(
    '%Y/%m/%d %H')
income = [20, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 5, 5, 50, 90, 0, 80, 120, 145, 30, 55, 40, 85, 95, 130, 70, 20, 70,
          100, 80, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 25, 0, 0, 20, 75, 70, 190, 20, 90, 245, 110, 170, 85, 110, 140,

          20, 80, 120, 120, 30, 70, 10, 30, 25, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 85, 0, 10, 100, 110, 145, 190, 190,
          135, 80, 35, 70, 80, 95, 130, 25, 0, 25, 20, 0, 5, 0, 0, 0, 20, 15, 130, 70, 50, 90, 70,
          90, 160, 80, 60, 160, 60, 30, 50, 50, 50, 40, 10, 0, 0, 0, 0, 20, 20, 10, 60, 30, 0, 50,

          50, 230, 90, 50, 140, 95, 80, 320, 120, 180, 30, 120, 0, 30, 5, 0, 0, 0, 5, 20, 25, 90,
          40, 0, 40, 10, 140, 30, 20, 60, 165, 105, 75, 30, 30, 120, 0, 50, 40, 10, 40, 5, 0, 40,
          55, 20, 5, 40, 20, 40, 210, 20, 115, 70, 0, 190, 135, 115, 140, 70, 50, 70]

df = pd.Series(income, index=hours)

# all values are NaN

# even addings just one hour to the training sample gives only NaNs

print(one_hour_outsample)
```

items.title: BUG: AdditiveGamSmoother.transform fails for 1-D arrays
items.body:
#### Describe the bug

Passing a 1-D numpy array, or a pandas DataFrame or Series as the `x` parameter to `BSplines` succeeds in returning a `BSplines` instance, but then fails to transform the same `x` when passed as the argument to `BSplines.transform`

#### Code Sample

```python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from statsmodels.gam.smooth_basis import BSplines

x = np.linspace(0, 1, 100)
df = pd.DataFrame(dict(x1=x, x2=x))

splines = BSplines(x, [6], [3])
splines.transform(x)

df_splines = BSplines(df, [6, 6], [3, 3])
df_splines.transform(df)

series_splines = BSplines(df["x1"], [6], [3])
series_splines.transform(df["x1"])
```
- A 1-D ndarray raises `IndexError: too many indices for array`
- A DataFrame raises `TypeError: '(slice(None, None, None), 0)' is an invalid key`
- A Series raises `ValueError: Can only tuple-index with a MultiIndex`

#### Expected Output

Transformed arrays

items.title: Use statsmodels under alternative name - modify .so files
items.body: Hello, I came across the need to use two statsmodels versions in the same environment (0.8.0 & 0.11.0). That happens because I'm trying to integrate a new product to an older environment that already uses statsmodels 0.8.0. My new product includes holt-winters model, which is not available in version 0.8.0. In order to achieve that, I cloned the repo and modified its name and all the import statements accordingly. The problem starts because directory **statsmodels.tsa.statespace** contains 6 encoded .so files that still refer to the old name. If anybody (owner or anyone else), possesses a working version of the so. files which refer to an alternative package name (e.g. not 'statsmodels'), and can share it with me, it would be great. I can accept any version that has the holt-winters model (0.11.0 is just an example). I already tried modifying it manually, I managed to access the file contents with the solution mentioned in this [link ](https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/372111/how-to-change-text-in-shared-libraries-so-files-in-linux?newreg=01e762bae2d048c8a18880940587713c), and figured out that the contents length should remain the same and that the hexadecimal values should be modified (and not the text). Yet, manual modification of each occasion correctly and accurately seems like an undoable work. What makes it so difficult is that the vim file search does not recognize line breaks (Illustration attached), and each occasion of 'statsmodels' can be cut after each character. So, it will require manual check of at least tens of thousands cases in each file. If you have any other solution for using two versions in the same environment, you may share as well. Thanks, Yaniv

items.title: VARMAXResults.extend() causes ValueError: array must not contain infs or NaNs
items.body:
#### Describe the bug

Extending a VARMAX model with new observations throws a ValueError even though the analogous univariate extend with same syntax works for SARIMAX.

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible


```python
from statsmodels.tsa.statespace.varmax import VARMAX
import numpy as np

np.random.seed(1)
y_hist = 100*np.random.rand(50,2)

model = VARMAX(endog= y_hist,order=(2,0)).fit()
print("VARMAX model summary")
print(model.summary())
next_y_hat = model.forecast()
print("\nPredicted next value")
print(next_y_hat)

# simulate next observed value
next_y = next_y_hat

# extend model
model = model.extend(endog = next_y) # ValueError: array must not contain infs or NaNs
```
<details>

The analogous use of SARIMAXResults.extend() works fine:

```python
from statsmodels.tsa.statespace.sarimax import SARIMAX

uni_model = SARIMAX(endog=y_hist[:,1],order=(2,0,0)).fit()
print("SARIMAX model summary")
print(uni_model.summary())
next_y_hat_uni = uni_model.forecast()
print("\nPredicted next value")
print(next_y_hat_uni)

# simulate next observed value
next_y_uni = next_y_hat_uni

# extend model
uni_model = uni_model.extend(endog = next_y_uni)
```

</details>

If the issue has not been resolved, please file it in the issue tracker.

#### Expected Output

`model.extend(endog = next_y)` should return a VARMAXResultsWrapper instead of ValueError

items.title: Issues with docstring example of OaxacaBlinder
items.body:
https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/1212616d27ab820d303377f0bcf421cd3f46c289/statsmodels/stats/oaxaca.py#L95-L103

This piece of documentation seems to have a couple of problems:

- `data = sm.datasets.ccards.load()` -> `data = sm.datasets.ccard.load()`
- `sm.OaxacaBlinder` does not seem to be valid way to access `OaxacaBlinder` for me.
- `sm.OaxacaBlinder(df.endog, df.exog, 3, hasconst = False)`: `df` -> `data`

This worked for me:

```python
>>> import numpy as np 
>>> from statsmodels.stats.oaxaca import OaxacaBlinder

>>> data = sm.datasets.ccard.load() 

>>> model = OaxacaBlinder(data.endog, data.exog, 3, hasconst = False) 
>>> model.two_fold().summary() 
```

Also note that the output in the [documentation](https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.stats.oaxaca.OaxacaBlinder.html) renders strangely:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15384900/88033010-1130a400-cb3f-11ea-9be2-aa18ddc59ba8.png)


xref: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/62995753/modules-missisng-in-statsmodels-python-oaxacablinder

items.title: Coint Johansen Test Returning Matrix is not positive definite
items.body:
#### Describe the bug

Trying to create a time-series forecast and had the coint_johansen test working previously, but when I added empty rows to represent the next 8 months, it stopped working. And now when I have reverted back to the original dataset, it is not working anymore; giving me the error that: LinAlgErrro: Matrix is not Positive Definite.

#### Code Sample

from statsmodels.tsa.vector_ar.vecm import coint_johansen

```
def cointegration_test(df, alpha=0.05): 
    """Perform Johanson's Cointegration Test and Report Summary"""
    out = coint_johansen(df,-1,5)
    d = {'0.90':0, '0.95':1, '0.99':2}
    traces = out.lr1
    cvts = out.cvt[:, d[str(1-alpha)]]
    def adjust(val, length= 6): return str(val).ljust(length)

    # Summary
    print('Name   ::  Test Stat > C(95%)    =>   Signif  \n', '--'*20)
    for col, trace, cvt in zip(df.columns, traces, cvts):
        print(adjust(col), ':: ', adjust(round(trace,2), 9), ">", adjust(cvt, 8), ' =>  ' , trace > cvt)

cointegration_test(df)


```
<details>
I have approx. 2400 rows of data with 29 features (2400 x 29 matrix) and when I ran the test yesterday, it worked fine but now for some reason its not working anymore. Any help is much appreciated.


</details>

items.title: get_prediction fails with regression models after calling remove_data and ndim=1 input
items.body:
#### Describe the bug

 the conditional expression at L160 in v0.11 regression._prediction.py will cause an AttributeError with a simple model (exog dim=1) if remove_data has been called on the underlying model. 

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

```python
import numpy as np
import statsmodels.api as sm

# toy data
endog = [i + np.random.normal(scale=0.1) for i in range(100)]
exog = [i for i in range(100)]

# fit 
model = sm.OLS(endog, exog, weights=[1 for _ in range(100)]).fit()
model.summary() # R^2 ~= 1
# works fine
model.get_prediction(1).predicted_mean
model.get_prediction([1]).predicted_mean
model.get_prediction([[1]]).predicted_mean

model.remove_data()
# works fine
model.get_prediction(1).predicted_mean
model.get_prediction([[1]]).predicted_mean

# AttributeError
model.get_prediction([1]).predicted_mean
```
<details>

**Note**: As you can see, there are many issues on our GitHub tracker, so it is very possible that your issue has been posted before. Please check first before submitting so that we do not have to handle and close duplicates.

items.title: ols incorrectly assumes string or bool datatype on float data from pandas dataframe
items.body:
Trying to perform a OLS fit of data from a pandas dataframe results in an error suggesting the underlying data is considered a categorical, but the data type is clearly a float. Converting the data to a list and back into a dataframe results in the successful completion of the fit even though the underlying data types haven't changed. 

The following code exemplifies the issue:

```python
from statsmodels.stats.diagnostic import het_white
from statsmodels.formula.api import gls
import statsmodels.api as sm

x = final_df['Age_at_death']
y = final_df['PTEN_gene']
print(type(final_df['PTEN_gene']))
print(type(final_df['PTEN_gene'][0]))
formula = 'y~x'
model = ols(formula=formula, data=final_df).fit()`
```
I get the following output
```
<class 'pandas.core.series.Series'>
<class 'float'>

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-770-ad64389a838d> in <module>
     16 #df1.reset_index(drop=True, inplace=True)
     17 formula1 = 'pten_freq~age'
---> 18 model1 = ols(formula=formula1, data=df1).fit()
     19 #results = model.fit()o
     20 #print(results.)

~/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/statsmodels/base/model.py in from_formula(cls, formula, data, subset, drop_cols, *args, **kwargs)
    175                              'columns that has shape {0}. This occurs when '
    176                              'the variable converted to endog is non-numeric'
--> 177                              ' (e.g., bool or str).'.format(endog.shape))
    178         if drop_cols is not None and len(drop_cols) > 0:
    179             cols = [x for x in exog.columns if x not in drop_cols]

ValueError: endog has evaluated to an array with multiple columns that has shape (55, 52). This occurs when the variable converted to endog is non-numeric (e.g., bool or str).
```
As you can see, the data type is float and not bool or str. Strangely, if I first convert the data to a list and then bring back into a new dataframe, the code completes as expected. The following code
```python
from statsmodels.stats.diagnostic import het_white
from statsmodels.formula.api import gls
import statsmodels.api as sm

x = final_df['Age_at_death'].tolist()
y = final_df['PTEN_gene'].tolist()
age = pd.Series(x)
pten_freq = pd.Series(y)

print(type(final_df['PTEN_gene']))
print(type(final_df['PTEN_gene'][0]))

df1 = pd.concat([pten_freq, age], axis=1)
df1.columns = ('pten_freq', 'age')
formula1 = 'pten_freq~age'
model1 = ols(formula=formula1, data=df1).fit()`
```
results in the successful completion and the following expected output:
```
<class 'pandas.core.series.Series'>
<class 'float'>
```
The underlying data and data types haven't changed.

items.title: Error catching in grangercausalitytest
items.body:
When passing a zero lag to `grangercausalitytests` in a list, such as in:

```python
granger = grangercausalitytests(df, maxlag=[0, 5, 10])
```

The expected behavior would be raising an exception (line 1197 of stattools.py):

```python
try:
        lags = np.array([int(lag) for lag in maxlag])
        maxlag = lags.max()
        if lags.min() <= 0 or lags.size == 0:
            raise ValueError('maxlag must be a non-empty list containing only '
                             'positive integers')
    except Exception:
        maxlag = int_like(maxlag, 'maxlag')
        if maxlag <= 0:
            raise ValueError('maxlag must a a positive integer')
        lags = np.arange(1, maxlag + 1)
```

However, this exception seems to be catched by the `except Exception` and pass `maxlag` (which now has the value of `lags.max()`) to `int_like`, as a result, the calculation is performed for all the lags from 1 to `maxlag.max()`. 

I think this could be fixed just by changing the `except Except` by `except TypeError`.

I can try and fix this myself, if that is ok.

thank you,

items.title: Is the DynamicFactor Model built to handle large panels of times series as input?
items.body:
Apologies in advance if this formatting does not follow a template, this is my first time posting here please let me know if any edits are needed.

I am working with the [DynamicFactor ](https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.tsa.statespace.dynamic_factor.DynamicFactor.html?highlight=dynamicfactor) model 

I noticed that when dealing with large panels +100 times series the estimation (.fit) takes very long time to run +2h or will raise an exception for non-positive definite forecast error covariance matrix.
Which raises the following questions :      

> -  Does the implementation of the dynamic factor model allows the work on large panels? With profiling the Kalman filtering is the step that takes too long to complete
> 
> -  In the same context of high dimensional panels, what are the reasons that lead to non-positive definite error forecast covariance matrices? Is it numerical stability ? This error causes the Cholesky inversion to raise a Linalg exception and changing Cholesky to LU causes memory errors (as well as working with non-valid covariance matrices).
> 
> - Is there a routine implemented to correct the non-positive definite covariance errors?

items.title: VAR - How to get one-step ahead static forecast?
items.body:
Hi, I do time series forecasting with VAR model. What I would like to be doing is, training the models with a training data, and use the model to generate one-step static forecast with a test data (take actual values to make next step forecast). So far, my code is shown as follows:

import statsmodels.api as sm
model = sm.tsa.VARMAX(train_data, order=(2, 0), trend='c')
model_result = model.fit(maxiter=1000, disp=False)
model_result.summary()

model_result.forecast(steps=7)

I believe this is a dynamic forecast (take previously forecasted values). Providing that the data is transformed into a stationary series by differencing, how can I use the same model estimated from the training data to try on the new unseen data in order to make 1 step-ahead static forecast?

I realize that it is possible to do that with SARIMAX #2788. Is it possible to do with VAR in a similar way?

items.title: REF: Empirical autocovariance is not unbiased even when dividing by n-k
items.body:
There is a flag `unbiased` when computing empirical autocovariance, e.g. here
https://www.statsmodels.org/devel/generated/statsmodels.graphics.tsaplots.plot_acf.html
(I suspect that this plotting function inherits this from some underlying function used to compute the ACF?)

However, the empirical autocovariance function is not unbiased even if we divide by n-k, so I wonder if this option should be removed, or at least renamed? See e.g. page 27 in https://www.stat.pitt.edu/stoffer/tsa4/tsa4.pdf

items.title: holtwinters SimpleExpSmoothing's out-of-sample  forcast calculations are wrong
items.body:
#### Describe the bug

In the [statsmodels tutorial](https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/examples/notebooks/generated/exponential_smoothing.html#Simple-Exponential-Smoothing), the out-of-sample  forecast values of "Simple Exponential Smoothing" are wrong.  

In the tutorial, three different fitted models is used to  forecast out-of-sample values. In each forecast , the fitted model will forecast 3 out-of-sample values, but the 3 values is the same. This can be seen clearly in **[the tutorial's plot](https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/_images/examples_notebooks_generated_exponential_smoothing_6_0.png)**, the last three dots of the same color will form a horizontal line.

And if you try the codes in the tutorial, you will find whatever value n you fill in the forecast() method, it will only return n same values. So it must be wrong.

import pandas as pd
from statsmodels.tsa.holtwinters import SimpleExpSmoothing

Motor = pd.read_csv("data/motororg.dat")

Motor.dat <- read.table("e:\\tmp\\timeseries\\motororg.dat",header=T)

ARIMA strange behavior depending on order of d. Am I completely wrong that it should work in both cases ? It casts origin_exog  to another size so size of feature does not fit anymore.
 

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

<details>

import pandas as pd
import statsmodels.api as sm
from pandas._libs.tslibs.timestamps import Timestamp

items.title: Different results for linear regression based on conda environment
items.body:
# Summary:
 I have noticed different results of the parameters I get as output when running simple linear regression (with ordinary least squares) on the qiime conda environment and other conda environments. I came across this issue when I ran code in a conda environment and got drastically different results than when I ran it in other conda environments. I am curious to know if anyone can give me a reason for this difference 
# Specifics: 
The two environments used were a qiime2-2020.2 environment (python 3.6.7, ```statsmodels==0.11.1```, ```scikit-learn==0.22.1```, and ```numpy===1.18.1```) and a standard  base conda environment (python 3.7.4, ```statsmodels==0.11.1```, ```scikit-learn==0.21.3```, and ```numpy===1.17.2```). My issue is that in the qiime environment, both statsmodels.api.OLS and sklearn.linear_model.LinearRegression give different values when fitted on the same input.  
# Sample code 
The following is some code that I use to observe the differenced in both. Here, *x.csv* is a csv of the design matrix used to fit and and *y.csv* is a csv of the response variable. The aim is for the code to fit 14 parameters (using ordinary least squares) on 303 samples. 
```
import statsmodels.api as sm
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd 
x= pd.read_csv("x.csv", delimiter=',',encoding='utf-8',index_col=0,low_memory=False)
y=pd.read_csv("y.csv", delimiter=',',encoding='utf-8',index_col=0,low_memory=False)
model = sm.OLS(y,x) res = model.fit()
print(res.params)
model=LinearRegression(fit_intercept=False).fit(x,y) print(model.coef_)
print((abs(res.params -model.coef_[0]).sum()))
``` 
# Results 
So right off the bat, we get different results when running this script the qiime environment and the base environment. The difference in the two is quite significant (for some parameters, the solutions differ by up to 27 orders of magnitude). When I looked into this further, it seems that all other environments I have run this script on have the same output as the base environment. Furthermore, within these agreeing environments, the sum of the absolute differences between the parameters estimated through sklearn and statsmodels is never greater that 1e-14 which is expected. However, in the qiime environment, this sum of differences is ~0.60. Recap:
| package\env                                                       | qiime  | base   |
|-------------------------------------------------------------------|--------|--------|
| python                                                            | 3.7.4  | 3.6.7  |
| pandas                                                            | 0.25.1 | 0.25.3 |
| scikit-learn                                                      | 0.22.1 | 0.21.3 |
| statsmodels                                                       | 0.11.1 | 0.11.1 |
| numpy                                                             | 1.17.2 | 1.18.1 |
| difference between statsmodels estimate  and scikit-lean estimate | .60    | 1e-14  |

 # Question 
I would welcome any explanation for the discrepancy between the **qiime** environment and the other conda environments. I am curious to know if this is an effect of the python version I am using or something completely different.

items.title: Out-of-sample likelihood of UnobservedComponents models
items.body:
Hey there. My end goal is to evaluate the stationarity of a time series by comparing the likelihood of a white noise process (i.e. `UnobservedComponents` model with `level = 'deterministic constant'`) and a plausible non-stationary model for the same series, in my case either a local level model or a random walk.

I would like to do this by computing an out-of-sample likelihood ratio statistic, if possible using the same sort of recursive forecasting as outlined in https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/examples/notebooks/generated/statespace_forecasting.html. However, instead of using RMSE as my score function, I want to use log-likelihood, for increased statistical efficiency. 

Given that `get_forecast()` allows me to compute a confidence interval, I presume that there is some built-in machinery I can leverage to calculate the predictive likelihood of a point forecast as opposed to its RMSE. Any pointers on how to do this would be appreciated; there's a lot happening in the `statespace` module and I haven't quite grasped how the classes work just yet.

Here's a short example demonstrating an in-sample likelihood calculation. If you can point out how to calculate the predictive likelihood on `test` that would be ideal!

``` python
import statsmodels.api as sm
import pandas as pd

sunspots = sm.datasets.sunspots.load_pandas().data

sunspots.columns = ['year', 'activity']
sunspots.year = pd.to_datetime(sunspots.year, format='%Y')

sunspots = sunspots.set_index('year').asfreq('AS')

train = sunspots.query('year < 2000')
test = sunspots.query('year >= 2000')

estimator = sm.tsa.UnobservedComponents(
    endog=train.activity,
    level='deterministic constant'
)

estimates = estimator.fit(method='powell', disp=False)

# in-sample likelihood on train
print(estimates.llf)
>>> -1532.6247359972863
```

items.title: Missing square in Cook's distances
items.body:
#### Describe the bug
According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cook%27s_distance#Definition), the $1-h_{ii}$ term in the calculation of Cook's distances should be squared. However, it is not in `statsmodels` [implementation](https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/15a0b635eb02d4c46cde5ad890310d15557737aa/statsmodels/stats/outliers_influence.py#L1251).

items.title: Logit much slower than sklearn LogisticRegression
items.body:
#### Describe the bug

Performance bug: statsmodels Logit regression is 10-100x slower than scikit-learn LogisticRegression.

I benchmarked both using L-BFGS solver, with the same number of iterations, and the same other settings as far as I can tell.

The speed difference seems to increase with larger data sets, and increase by a huge amount when using fit_regularized().  On dataset 10k samples x 1k features, fit_regularized() with l1 penalty can take more than a day, where scikit-learn with l2 penalty takes a couple of seconds.  

On my production data, statsmodels is so slow as to be essentially unusable.

I'm also wondering if the two version of logit somehow work in a completely different way: is this only a performance bug, or a performance difference that is due to a significant difference in the way the optimization problem is posed? (and consequently with different results)

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

```python
import statsmodels.api as sm
import sklearn.datasets
import sklearn.linear_model # sklearn 0.22.1
X_train, y_train = sklearn.datasets.make_classification(n_samples=30000, n_features=2048, n_informative=2048, n_redundant=0, n_repeated=0)
%time model = sm.Logit(y_train, X_train).fit(method='lbfgs', pgtol=0.0001, maxiter=10, disp=True, qc_verbose=True)
# CPU times: user 37.5 s, sys: 1.4 s, total: 38.8 s Wall time: 9.98 s
%time model = sklearn.linear_model.LogisticRegression(max_iter=10, penalty='none', verbose=1).fit(X_train, y_train)
# CPU times: user 1.22 s, sys: 7.95 ms, total: 1.23 s Wall time: 339 ms
```
<details>

Both stop at max_iter in this example, so the result is not affected by the convergence criteria.  If max_iter is increased, scikit-learn converges in 35 iterations annd 3.6 CPU seconds, while statsmodels converges in 17 iterations and 38.8 CPU seconds.

Environment: AWS g4dn instance, AWS Deep Learning AMI Version 29.0
</details>



#### Expected Output

I would expect the run time to be similar when using the same solver and same data.

items.title: how to run a glm func without a DeprecationWarning？
items.body:
hello， 
Following is my code, and what i want is to use a freq_weights in logit regression.
I find a method to do that which is using a GLM function as the code shows.
The code runs successfully but throws up a Deprecation Warning. (DeprecationWarning: Calling Family(..) with a link class as argument is deprecated.)
How to get rid of this warning? Thanks a lot.

```
import statsmodels.api as sm
spector_data = sm.datasets.spector.load_pandas()
x_var = spector_data.exog
x_var = sm.add_constant(x_var)
x_var['wt'] = x_var.apply(lambda x: np.random.randint(1,10), axis=1)
model = sm.GLM(spector_data.endog,  x_var.iloc[:, x_var.columns != 'wt'], \
               family=sm.families.Binomial(sm.families.links.logit), freq_weights=x_var['wt'])
```

items.title: REF: catch convergence warning for initial optimization in discrete/count models
items.body:
count models use a preliminary estimate, e.g. Poisson, to get better start_params for fitting more complex models like ZIP.

It is confusing to see the convergence warning for the initial estimate when the final estimate converged.

I think currently only count models are affected by this.
(GLM has a start_irls, but, IIRC, irls never issues a convergence warning.)

items.title: What's the meaning of the result of grangercausalitytests?
items.body:
When I use statsmodels' grangercausalitytests, the result is like this:
gc_res2 = grangercausalitytests(data, 10)

Granger Causality
number of lags (no zero) 1
ssr based F test:         F=28.7248 , p=0.0000  , df_denom=198, df_num=1
ssr based chi2 test:   chi2=29.1600 , p=0.0000  , df=1
likelihood ratio test: chi2=27.2295 , p=0.0000  , df=1
parameter F test:         F=28.7248 , p=0.0000  , df_denom=198, df_num=1

Granger Causality
number of lags (no zero) 2
ssr based F test:         F=18.9880 , p=0.0000  , df_denom=195, df_num=2
ssr based chi2 test:   chi2=38.9498 , p=0.0000  , df=2
likelihood ratio test: chi2=35.5873 , p=0.0000  , df=2
parameter F test:         F=18.9880 , p=0.0000  , df_denom=195, df_num=2

Granger Causality
number of lags (no zero) 3
ssr based F test:         F=13.5015 , p=0.0000  , df_denom=192, df_num=3
ssr based chi2 test:   chi2=41.9812 , p=0.0000  , df=3
likelihood ratio test: chi2=38.0914 , p=0.0000  , df=3
parameter F test:         F=13.5015 , p=0.0000  , df_denom=192, df_num=3

Granger Causality
number of lags (no zero) 4
ssr based F test:         F=10.9646 , p=0.0000  , df_denom=189, df_num=4
ssr based chi2 test:   chi2=45.9467 , p=0.0000  , df=4
likelihood ratio test: chi2=41.3192 , p=0.0000  , df=4
parameter F test:         F=10.9646 , p=0.0000  , df_denom=189, df_num=4

I use command: gc_res2 = grangercausalitytests(data, 4)

The x1 and x2 in data have passed the ADF test, which show that they are both stationary.
What I want to ask is, how to understand the output(the result)?
for example, in number of lags (no zero) 4,
ssr based F test:         F=10.9646 , p=0.0000  , df_denom=189, df_num=4
does it mean that X2(t-4)'s impact to X1(t)  is none because the p value < 0.05 and the coefficient of  X2(t-4) to X1(t) is zero ? ( base on F test )
If I want to say, X2 is the granger causeto X1, the  p value in all numbers of lags should be < 0.05 or 0.01(fixed before do this test), right? and if anyone of (numbers of lags 1, or 2 or 31, or any ) these's p value > fixed value, we shouldn't reject the null hypothesis that X2 isn't the granger causeto X1, right?
I'm not sure whether my understanding is right...

items.title: AttributeError when calling OLSResults.resid after calling OLS.fit() in one line, but not over two lines
items.body:
#### Bug description

There is an inconsistency that occurs between 

1. Calling `OLS(y, x).fit()` on a single line and then generating the OLSResults object, and

2. Calling `lm=OLS(y, x)` on one line, and then `lm.fit()` on a second line and then generating the OLSResults object.

Case (2) results in an error when applying methods of the OLSResults object, but case (1) does not. Sample below.

#### Code Sample

```
import pandas as pd
from statsmodels.datasets import get_rdataset
from statsmodels.regression import linear_model
from statsmodels.tools import add_constant

data = get_rdataset("Boston", package="MASS", cache=False)
df = data.data

df['lstat2'] = df.lstat ** 2

X = df.filter(['lstat', 'lstat2'], axis=1)
X = add_constant(X, prepend=True)
y = df.medv

# Case 1 (works fine)
model1 = linear_model.OLS(y, X)
output1 = model1.fit()
params1, covs1 = output1.params, output1.normalized_cov_params
results1 = linear_model.OLSResults(model1, params1, covs1)
residuals1 = results1.resid

# Case 2 (AttributeError)
model2 = linear_model.OLS(y, X).fit()
params2, covs2 = model2.params, model2.normalized_cov_params
results2 = linear_model.OLSResults(model2, params2, covs2)
residuals2 = results2.resid
```

items.title: Documentation Error: SARIMAX
items.body:
The documentation for the `trend` argument of [SARIMAX](https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.tsa.statespace.sarimax.SARIMAX.html#statsmodels.tsa.statespace.sarimax.SARIMAX) states:

_Can also be specified as an iterable defining the polynomial as in numpy.poly1d, where [1,1,0,1] would denote $a+bt+ct^3$_

But the documentation for [numpy.poly1d](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.poly1d.html) states that the coefficients should be supplied _in decreasing powers_ meaning the array should be [1,0,1,1]?

Also a minor issue with section `seasonal_order`, the text refers to p, q, and d in places - it should be P, Q, and D.

Finally, it's not clear what form the lag polynomials take, i.e. (1 - \phi_1 B - \phi_2 B^2 ...) or (1 + \phi_1 B + \phi_2 B^2 ...). From [ArmaProcess](https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.tsa.arima_process.ArmaProcess.html) it seems the AR polynomials are -ve and the MA are +ve.

items.title: Documentation Error: AutoReg
items.body:
The `cov_kwds` for `cov_type='HAC'` is documented as `maxlag` but it appears the correct keyword is `maxlags`

https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.tsa.ar_model.AutoReg.fit.html#statsmodels.tsa.ar_model.AutoReg.fit

items.title: Add Root Mean Square Percentage Error to evaluation measures
items.body:
#### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe
There are many cases in which a Percentage Error is a more appropriate measure of model fit than an Absolute Error.

#### Describe the solution you'd like
I have added a simple Root Mean Square Percentage Error function, for which I am ready to make a pull request.

#### Additional context
The only complexity is handling zero values. My function includes a parameter in which the user is able to specify whether they would like the zero-value case to return `np.nan` (default) or some other value.

items.title: arima_model or arima.model, two classes, lots of confusion
items.body:
I was looking at some examples yesterday night to solve an issue re invertibility and then I noticed the presence of arima_model and arima.model which is confusing.

The latter seems to be the master class, and the first the wrapper, but the lack of documentation doesn't help.

I just find this out as a chance because of the enforce_inversability param that is missing on the first.

items.title: Weighted IV2SLS

#### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe
I'd like to use observation weights in IV2SLS models.

#### Describe the solution you'd like
An optional argument to specify weights, as in WLS.

#### Describe alternatives you have considered
[`linearmodels IV2SLS`](https://bashtage.github.io/linearmodels/iv/iv/linearmodels.iv.model.IV2SLS.html#linearmodels.iv.model.IV2SLS) accepts weights, as do R's [`AER ivreg`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/AER/versions/1.2-9/topics/ivreg) and [`lfe felm`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/lfe/versions/2.8-5/topics/felm).

items.title: Specify constant column in add_constant(has_constant='raise') when it already exists
items.body:
#### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe
I called `add_constant` to a dataset which had an existing constant, but I didn't know which column it was.

#### Describe the solution you'd like
Mention the constant column identified when throwing the error in `add_constant(has_constant='raise')`.

#### Describe alternatives you have considered
One could find it themselves by looping through columns and taking the variance.

#### Additional context
The current error is:
```
ValueError: x contains a constant. Adding a constant with trend='c' is not allowed.
```

When X is an array or something other than a DataFrame, the error could specify the column number instead.

items.title: Possible typo on  the page
items.body:
[On this page](https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.tsa.statespace.exponential_smoothing.ExponentialSmoothing.html) under notes, it's written that _the statespace exponential smoothing is worse than sm.tsa.ExponentialSmoothing_ There is no sm.tsa.ExponentialSmoothing class. Did you mean sm.tsa.holtwinters.ExponentialSmoothing ? Please clarify and please add a link to the referenced class.

Thanks

items.title: BUG: dataframe/series concatenation in statespace results append
items.body:
So, here's my code:

```
df = pd.read_csv('spy1m.txt')
spy1m = pd.Series(list(df['return']), index=pd.to_datetime(df['date']), name='data').asfreq('M', 'pad')

nobs = len(spy1m)
ntrain = len(spy1m)//2
train = spy1m[:ntrain]
mod = tsa.SARIMAX(train, orders=(2, 0, 2))
res = mod.fit()
forecasts = []
forecasts.append(res.forecast(steps=1))

for i in range(ntrain, nobs):
    res = res.append(spy1m.iloc[i:i+1])
    fc = res.forecast(steps=1)
    forecasts.append(fc)
```

This code trains the model on the first half of the data and then tries to use it to predict the second half. Unfortunately, almost all the forecasts are zero:

```
pd.concat(forecasts).plot()
```
![graph1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1126907/83058106-d706c280-a025-11ea-8cd9-d4811899a4cb.png)

items.title: Question: Do all ARMA/ARIMA examples in docs have lookahead bias?
items.body:
If I just use the `predict()` function (like in the examples), it seems to me that we're predicting values based on data we used to generate the parameters of the model Let's say that every day I get some new time series data and I want to predict the next days data. What is the best way to do this?

Do I need to have a rolling window and fit and then forecast one step ahead over and over again? 

What if instead of a rolling window, I want to fit the parameters based on training data and then use it on out of sample data? How would I do this? Could someone give me some code samples? It doesn't seem like statsmodel makes this easy. I find it confusing that all this emphasis is placed on the predict function, when it seems to me that the results are necessarily invalid. Unless predict only uses samples in the past to fit the model? But I don't think that is true because fitting is relegated to a different method. 

Edit: I found this is the documentation:

```
Note: These are technically in-sample since the data we are forecasting was used to estimate parameters. Producing OOS forecasts requires two models. The first must exclude the OOS period. The second uses the predict method from the full-sample model with the parameters from the shorter sample model that excluded the OOS period.
```

Could someone give me an example of how to do this? Is the following correct?

```
arma = tsa.ARMA(in_sample, (2, 2)).fit()
arma.initialize(tsa.ARMA(out_sample, (2, 2)), arma.params)
```

items.title: VARResults.irf_resim raises ValueError when exog variables are used
items.body:
#### Describe the bug

It seems `VARResults.irf_resim` raises `ValueError: endog and exog matrices are different sizes` when exog variables are used. Using the example from the [documentation](https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/vector_ar.html), it runs fine without any exog variables:

```python
# some example data
import numpy as np

import pandas

import statsmodels.api as sm

from statsmodels.tsa.api import VAR

mdata = sm.datasets.macrodata.load_pandas().data

# prepare the dates index
dates = mdata[['year', 'quarter']].astype(int).astype(str)

quarterly = dates["year"] + "Q" + dates["quarter"]

from statsmodels.tsa.base.datetools import dates_from_str

quarterly = dates_from_str(quarterly)

mdata = mdata[['realgdp','realcons','realinv']]

mdata.index = pandas.DatetimeIndex(quarterly)

data = np.log(mdata).diff().dropna()

# make a VAR model
model = VAR(data)

results = model.fit(maxlags=1)
irf_sim = results.irf_resim(orth=False, repl=100, steps=10, seed=1, burn=100, cum=False)
```

However, if I add an exog variable,

```python
data_exog = pandas.DataFrame(index=data.index)
data_exog['exovar1'] = np.random.normal(size=data_exog.shape[0])

# make a VAR model
model_with_exog = VAR(endog=data, exog=data_exog)

results_with_exog = model_with_exog.fit(maxlags=1)

items.title: replicate R's mantelhaen.test with statsmodels.stats.contingency_tables.StratifiedTable().oddsratio_pooled
items.body:
I'm having trouble reproducing the odds ratio output from R's `mantelhaen.test` function - `mantelhaen.test()$estimate`.

Across different tests i perform, the `oddsratio_pool` matches with some of the R function outputs, while the rest do not. But if I switch columns or rows in my stratified tables, I can get the the R output for the tests that I previously could not reproduce, but now the previous tests I did reproduce are incorrect.

Is it as simple as updating the following method?:
```
    def oddsratio_pooled(self):
        """
        The pooled odds ratio.

        The value is an estimate of a common odds ratio across all of the
        stratified tables.
        """

        if sum(self._bc) <= sum(self._ad):
            odds_ratio = np.sum(self._ad / self._n) / np.sum(self._bc / self._n)
        else:
            odds_ratio = np.sum(self._bc / self._n) / np.sum(self._ad / self._n)

        return odds_ratio
```

Any other suggestions as to why I'm only getting the odds ratio from `mantelhaen.test` some of the time?

Thanks!

items.title: Add another nan-handling method in acf()
items.body:
#### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

#6641/#6726 revealed that `acf(..., missing="conservative")` did not behave as I would have hoped, and I would thus like to request a new nan-handling policy.  Specifically, it would seem reasonable to have a policy where the n-th lag acf of `t` is computed as something like `np.nanmean(t[:n] * t[-n:])` (with the correct centering and rescaling), i.e. dropping the nan terms in the sum (which "conservative" does, by setting them to zero) but also in the denominator when computing the mean.  The final rescaling should also be done by `np.nanmean(t**2)`, i.e. here too nans should be dropped from the denominator.

#### Describe the solution you'd like
Add a `missing="???"` policy to `acf()` which implements the approach above.  Name up to bikeshedding...

#### Describe alternatives you have considered
None that I can think of.

#### Additional context
N/A

items.title: STL Trend Smoother Default
items.body:
The STL parameters include a parameter for the trend smoother component, with the default being:

1.5 * period

In Cleveland's 1990 paper, he suggests the default trend smoother to be greater than or equal to:

1.5 * period / (1 - (1.5 / seasonal_smoother))

See page 18 [here](https://search.proquest.com/openview/cc5001e8a0978a6c029ae9a41af00f21/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=105444)

Is there a reason 1.5 * period was selected over Cleveland's suggestion?

items.title: Improve error messaging for common OLS mistake w/ categorical data.
items.body:
#### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

A common mistake of learners or just people who are working fast and not paying a lot of attention is to try to use OLS regression with a categorical dependent variable, often described by a string.  The error messaging for this can be really unhelpful though.  

Toy example from a problem that a student of mine just got bitten by, where `df` is a pandas data frame in wide format with 6345 observations, `foo` is a categorical variable with 3 classes denoted by strings, and `bar` is a float: 

```
import statsmodels.formula.api as sm
reg = sm.ols(formula='foo ~ bar', data=df)
f = reg.fit()
print(f.summary())
```

This is a mistake, the student should be using `mnlogit` rather than `ols`.  It should be a pretty readily detectable mistake from the statsmodels side: it's never right to have a column of strings as the dependent variable in an OLS regression.  But the error they get is really painful: 

```
ValueError: shapes (6345,3) and (6345,3) not aligned: 3 (dim 1) != 6345 (dim 0)
```

This is obviously some kind of error thrown from deep within numpy that is not only meaningless, but even actively confusing to people who aren't experienced with all the ways that numpy represents data shapes, broadcasting, etc. etc. (natural first thought: "how could (6345,3) and (6345,3) not be aligned?  they're the same tuple!").

Making matters worse, they don't get this error on the creation of the model, or on the call to `fit()` where it might make sense---as far as they know, they successfully fit a model, at least up to the point they try to actually view the output with `summary()` and only then is an error thrown.

(Prior issue where someone ran into this: #4794 )

#### Describe the solution you'd like

Statsmodels should check the type of the left-hand variable when an OLS function is called, and if it isn't numeric (or I guess boolean if people really really insist on using OLS instead of logit or whev for two-class categoricals) it should throw an error right away, either on initializing the model with `ols()` or on fitting it with `fit()`.  And that error should be geared toward people who might not realize their data isn't numeric, or who might not realize that it's a bad idea to throw OLS at everything.  For example, it could be a `ValueError` with a message like "Dependent variable in OLS regression must be numeric." 

#### Describe alternatives you have considered

If there are conceivable use cases where someone might want to try to run an OLS with a column of strings on the left side (and can somehow get them to work?!), I guess throw a warning?  But really, this should just be a clear error.

#### Additional context

I'm happy to work on a PR myself if there's interest in this.

items.title: [Doc] Discrepancy in default scale description
items.body:
[Here](https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/master/statsmodels/genmod/generalized_linear_model.py#L963), it says chi-square divided by `df_resid` which is supported by the [code](https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/master/statsmodels/genmod/generalized_linear_model.py#L772).

On the other hand, [here](https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/master/statsmodels/genmod/generalized_linear_model.py#L741) it says chi-square only.

The discrepancy gets propagated to the docstring where we would look in the first place to understand the method. So, we should fix it. Happy to submit a PR if I am right.

items.title: Clustered one-sample t-test ~ constant WLS with robust covariance
items.body:
(Note that I am not a statistician.)

I am looking for an implementation of a clustered one-sample t-test (actually, a paired t-test), but couldn't find one. I would like to test the mean of the cluster means against 0, without discarding all the  intra-cluster information. I have ~45 clusters and a variable number of instances per cluster (with a median of 3).

I found out that the p-values of linear regression are determined through a t-test, and that statsmodels offers cluster-robust p-values, so I could in effect get what I want by fitting a linear model on a single constant variable. I have the following questions:

* Do you see anything wrong with this approach? 
* Since I want to test the mean of the cluster means, I should use WLR with weights 1/m^2 where m is the cluster size, correct? Or should that be simply 1/m?
* What literature is the statsmodels implementation of the cluster-correction of the t-test based on?
* If this approach really amounts to a clustered one-sample t-test, might I suggest exposing it in the api as a dedicated function?

```
Here the code in the notation of the example in the docs. (Following the notation in the tutorial link above produced the same error)
```
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd 
import statsmodels.api as sm 

nile = sm.datasets.nile.load_pandas().data['volume']
nile.index = pd.date_range('1871', '1970', freq='AS')

class LocalLevel(sm.tsa.statespace.MLEModel):

    def __init__(self, endog):
        k_states = k_posdef = 1
        super().__init__(endog, 
            k_states = k_states,
            k_posdef = k_posdef,
            initialization='approximate_diffuse',

        self.ssm['design', 0, 0] = 1.0

        @property

        def start_params(self):
            return [1.0, 1.0]

        def transform_params(self,params):
            return params**2

        def untransform_params(self,params):
            return params**0.5

        def update(self, params, *args, **kwargs):
            params = super().update(params, *args, **kwargs)

            self.ssm['obs_cov', 0,0] = params[0]
            self.ssm['state_cov', 0,0] = params[1]

nile_model = LocalLevel(nile)

print(nile_model.loglike([15099.0,1469.1]))
```
This happened in both the conda environment which uses statsmodel version 0.9.0 and in my virtual environment with version 0.11.1 using python 3.7.

            sig_31, sig_32, sig_33 =  0., 0., 0.7
            sig_41, sig_42, sig_43, sig_44 =  0., 0., 0., 0.3
            sig_51, sig_52, sig_53, sig_54, sig_55 =  0., 0., 0., 0., 0.9
            return np.array([phi_11, phi_12, phi_13, phi_14, phi_15,
                             phi_21, phi_22, phi_23, phi_24, phi_25,
                             phi_31, phi_32, phi_33, phi_34, phi_35,
                             phi_41, phi_42, phi_43, phi_44, phi_45,
                             phi_51, phi_52, phi_53, phi_54, phi_55,
                            sig_11, 
                            sig_21, sig_22, 
                            sig_31, sig_32, sig_33, 
                            sig_41, sig_42, sig_43, sig_44, 
                            sig_51, sig_52, sig_53, sig_54, sig_55])
    
    
    
    def block_diag(a, b, n1, n2):
        """
        Create block diagonal matrix of this form:
         a*I |  0
        -----+-----
         0   |  b*I
         The size of the upper left corner is (n1, n1)
         The size of the lower right corner is (n2, n2)
        """
        upper_left = np.identity(n1)*a
        lower_right = np.identity(n2)*b
        upper_right = np.zeros((n1, n2))
        lower_left = np.zeros((n2, n1))
        upper = np.column_stack((upper_left, upper_right))
        lower = np.column_stack((lower_left, lower_right))
        z0 = np.row_stack((upper, lower))
        return z0
    
    
    def vec_tril(x, order='C'):
        """
        Reverse half-vectorization into a triangular matrix in the order of C or F(ortran)
        If x is complex, ivech(x) is conjugate symmetric.
        That is, ivech(x) = ivech(x).transpose().conj()
        """
        r = len(x)
        n = np.int((np.sqrt(1+8*r)-1)/2)
        # if all(np.isreal(x)):
        #     a_mat = np.zeros((n, n))
        # else:
        #     a_mat = np.zeros((n, n), 'complex')
        #although you want the dtype to be complex. i.e. np.isreal(np.array([1, 2, 3]) + 0j) returns True.
        a_mat = np.zeros((n, n), dtype=x.dtype)
        
        if order == 'C':
            d = np.tril_indices(n)
            a_mat[d] = x
        else:
            a_mat[:, 0] = x[0:n]
            oldindex = n
            for ii in np.arange(1, n):
                newindex = oldindex + n - ii
                a_mat[ii:n, ii] = x[oldindex:newindex]
                oldindex = newindex
        return a_mat
    
    
    
    # =============================================================================
    # SS fit
    # =============================================================================
    #train
    mdf0 = fredmd
    # model = MFVAR(mdf0)
    mdf1 = mdf0 [:int(mdf0.shape[0]*0.8)]
    model = MFVAR(mdf1)
    res = model.fit()
    print(res.summary())
    
    
    # #test
    mdf2 = mdf0 [int(mdf0.shape[0]*0.8):]
    model_pre = res.extend(mdf2)
    print(model_pre.summary())
    
    
    mphi = res.params[0:25].to_numpy().reshape(5,5)
    a = np.zeros((5, 5), float)
    np.fill_diagonal(a, vec_tril(res.params[25:]).diagonal())
    msigma = vec_tril(res.params[25:]) + vec_tril(res.params[25:]).T - a
    
    # pd.DataFrame(mphi).to_csv("mphi _py.csv")
    # pd.DataFrame(msigma).to_csv("msigma_py.csv")
    fcast_res2 = res.get_forecast(steps=5)
    # Note: since we did not specify the alpha parameter, the
    # confidence level is at the default, 95%
    print(fcast_res2.summary_frame())

items.title: got multiple values for argument 'constraints', 'bounds'
items.body:
#### Describe the bug
error happens when provide "bounds" or "constraints" option for scipy minimize

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

```python
~/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/statsmodels/base/optimizer.py in _fit_minimize(f, score, start_params, fargs, kwargs, disp, maxiter, callback, retall, full_output, hess)
    273 
    274     res = optimize.minimize(f, start_params, args=fargs, method=kwargs['min_method'],
--> 275                             jac=score, hess=hess, callback=callback, options=options)
    276 
    277     xopt    = res.x

~/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/scipy/optimize/_minimize.py in minimize(fun, x0, args, method, jac, hess, hessp, bounds, constraints, tol, callback, options)
    616     elif meth == 'slsqp':
    617         return _minimize_slsqp(fun, x0, args, jac, bounds,
--> 618                                constraints, callback=callback, **options)
    619     elif meth == 'trust-constr':
    620         return _minimize_trustregion_constr(fun, x0, args, jac, hess, hessp,

TypeError: _minimize_slsqp() got multiple values for argument 'constraints'

```
<details>

This happens when a keyword argument is specified that overwrites a positional argument. 
as scipy minimize already has bounds, constraints in the signature, and the options pass the bunds and constraints again. 

It should handled the same way as jac and hess, thank you
</details>


If the issue has not been resolved, please file it in the issue tracker.

#### Expected Output

Run without give error

items.title: Handle pathlib paths with `get_file_obj`
Time trend orders in augmented Dickey Fuller unit root test
items.body:
Hello,

Currently the function _adfuller_ supports only 4 different time trends, cf doc below:
>     regression : {'c','ct','ctt','nc'}
>         Constant and trend order to include in regression.
> 
>         * 'c' : constant only (default).
>         * 'ct' : constant and trend.
>         * 'ctt' : constant, and linear and quadratic trend.
>         * 'nc' : no constant, no trend.

I would be happy to work on the generalisation for a trend of an arbitrary order.

However, I had a look at the code and I'm not sure on the best way to implement this feature. Indeed, for trend order greater than 2 it becomes unhandy to use strings. I would rather specify the trend order using an int but this implies an in-depth change of the tool function _add_trend_.

What are your thoughts on this?

items.title: Implement a plot.figure(figsize=(w, h)) or an argument to allow figure size to be specified
items.body:
#### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe
The plot method allows the figure to be changed by importing the base matplotlib class and using the rcParams only.

#### Describe the solution you'd like
It would be nicer having a `plot.figure = [w, h]` or a `plot(figuresize=[w, h])` method to get that changed

#### Additional context
To date I have had never a need to import the matplotlib library on its own, and doing it just to set the figure size doesn't sound optimal.

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

    from abc import ABC
    import statsmodels.api as sm
    import numpy as np
    np.random.seed(42)
    
    
    # Global parameters
    nburn = 0
    nsim = 1000
    
    
    class MFVAR(sm.tsa.statespace.MLEModel, ABC):
        def __init__(self, endog):
            dummy_quarterly_obs = dummy_generator()
            n1 = 1   # number of quarterly variables (y)
            n2 = 1   # number of monthly variables (x)
            ns = (n1+n2)*5  # number of state variables
            tlen, nv = endog.shape   # number of observed v. & time length
            # actually, nv = n1+n2
            self.n1, self.n2, self.ns, self.nv = n1, n2, ns, nv
    
            super().__init__(endog, k_states=ns, k_posdef=nv,
                             initialization='stationary')
    
            # 1. time-varying design matrix Z[t]
            z0 = block_diag(1.0/3.0, 1.0, n1, n2)
            z1 = block_diag(2.0/3.0, 0.0, n1, n2)
            z2 = block_diag(1.0, 0.0, n1, n2)
            z3 = block_diag(2.0/3.0, 0.0, n1, n2)
            z4 = block_diag(1.0/3.0, 0.0, n1, n2)
            z = np.column_stack((z0, z1, z2, z3, z4))
            z0_u = block_diag(0.0, 1.0, n1, n2)
            z_u = np.column_stack((z0_u, np.zeros((nv, nv*4))))
            z_time = np.zeros((nv, ns, tlen))
            for t in range(tlen):
                if dummy_quarterly_obs[t]:
                    z_time[:, :, t] = z
                else:
                    z_time[:, :, t] = z_u
            self['design'] = z_time
    
            # # 2. time-varying observation disturbance H[t]
            # when y is observable
            h = np.zeros((nv, nv))
            # when y is unobservable
            h_u = block_diag(1.0, 0.0, n1, n2)  # random variable N(0, 1)
            h_time = np.zeros((nv, nv, tlen))
            for t in range(tlen):
                if dummy_quarterly_obs[t]:
                    h_time[:, :, t] = h
                else:
                    h_time[:, :, t] = h_u
            self['obs_cov'] = h_time
            # self['obs_cov'] = np.eye(nv)
    
            # 3. time-invariant selection matrix R
            self['selection'] = np.eye(ns, nv)
    
        def update(self, params, transformed=True, **kwargs):
            n1, n2, ns, nv = self.n1, self.n2, self.ns, self.nv
            # nv = n1 + n2
            # ns = 5 * nv
    
            # 4. time-invariant transition matrix T
            var_coef = params[:nv**2].reshape(nv, nv)
            var_coef = np.column_stack((var_coef, np.zeros((nv, nv*4))))
            self['transition'] = np.row_stack((var_coef, np.eye(nv*4, ns)))
    
            # 5. time-invariant state covariance Q
            tril_state_cov = vec_tril(params[nv**2:])   # lower-triangular matrix
            self['state_cov'] = tril_state_cov @ tril_state_cov.transpose()
    
        @property
        def start_params(self):
            phi_11, phi_12, phi_21, phi_22 = 0.8, 0., 0., 0.8   # initial guess
            sig_11, sig_12, sig_22 = 1.0, 0., 1.0
            return np.array([phi_11, phi_12, phi_21, phi_22, sig_11, sig_12, sig_22])
    
    
    def block_diag(a, b, n1, n2):
        """
        Create block diagonal matrix of this form:
         a*I |  0
        -----+-----
         0   |  b*I
         The size of the upper left corner is (n1, n1)
         The size of the lower right corner is (n2, n2)
        """
        upper_left = np.identity(n1)*a
        lower_right = np.identity(n2)*b
        upper_right = np.zeros((n1, n2))
        lower_left = np.zeros((n2, n1))
        upper = np.column_stack((upper_left, upper_right))
        lower = np.column_stack((lower_left, lower_right))
        z0 = np.row_stack((upper, lower))
        return z0
    
    
    def vec_tril(x, order='C'):
        """
        Reverse half-vectorization into a triangular matrix in the order of C or F(ortran)
        If x is complex, ivech(x) is conjugate symmetric.
        That is, ivech(x) = ivech(x).transpose().conj()
        """
        r = len(x)
        n = np.int((np.sqrt(1+8*r)-1)/2)
        # if all(np.isreal(x)):
        #     a_mat = np.zeros((n, n))
        # else:
        #     a_mat = np.zeros((n, n), 'complex')
        #although you want the dtype to be complex. i.e. np.isreal(np.array([1, 2, 3]) + 0j) returns True.
        a_mat = np.zeros((n, n), dtype=x.dtype)
        
        if order == 'C':
            d = np.tril_indices(n)
            a_mat[d] = x
        else:
            a_mat[:, 0] = x[0:n]
            oldindex = n
            for ii in np.arange(1, n):
                newindex = oldindex + n - ii
                a_mat[ii:n, ii] = x[oldindex:newindex]
                oldindex = newindex
        return a_mat
    
    
    def dummy_generator():
        dummy = [1, 0, 0]*nsim
        dummy = np.array(dummy, dtype=int)
        return dummy
    
    
    def data_generator():
        # % artificial data
        phi_11, phi_12, phi_21, phi_22 = 0.8, 0., 0., 0.5  # initial guess
        sig_11, sig_12, sig_22 = 0.5, 0.0, 0.5
        params = [phi_11, phi_12, phi_21, phi_22, sig_11, sig_12, sig_22]
        params = np.array(params)
        model_true = MFVAR(np.zeros((nsim*3, 2)))
        consumption = model_true.simulate(params, nsim*3)  # % consumption
        # consumption = np.delete(consumption, np.arange(burn))
        return consumption
    
    
    # SS fit
